designations.source: Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006 - Species of Principal Importance in England (section 41)
designations.source_description: Sections 41 (England) of the Natural Environment and Rural Communities Act 2006 require the listing of species of principal importance for the purpose of conserving biodiversity and therefore need to be taken into consideration by a public body when performing any of its functions with a view to conserving biodiversity.

designations.source: A review of the Hemiptera of Great Britain: The Aquatic and Semi-aquatic Bugs
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national status of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs using IUCN methodology for assessing threat. It covers all species of aquatic and semi-aquatic bugs (Heteroptera) in Great Britain, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and non-native species. A.A. Cook November 2015.
designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: A taxon is Vulnerable when it is not Critically Endangered or Endangered but is facing a high risk of extinction in the wild in the medium term future.
designations.comments: Recorded from the Norfolk Broads and Pevensey Levels, East Sussex. Recent records outside known range (on NBN Gateway) were confirmed as misidentifications. There are no recent records for the New Forest, where it has been found in the past. Nearly all the Norfolk records are from Catfield and adjoining fens and marshes (Sutton Fen, Turf Fen, Reedham Marsh). Water has been abstracted from Catfield Fen since 1986 and this has resulted in damaging changes in pH and water levels. As neighbouring fens are also affected this whole area constitutes one location (see IUCN guidelines). There are two other sites in East Norfolk (Burgh Common and Bure Marshes) that should be classed as additional locations. Records from the Pevensey levels all come from a fairly small area north east of Westham that constitute one location subject to threats of drainage, alien aquatic plants and sea-level rise. On the basis of a small known AOO (?40 km2), restricted number of locations (<5) and known threats to habitats (RSPB 2007, JNCC 2010 & other refs) H. gracilenta satisfies IUCN criteria for the status of  VU.

designations.source: UK list of Priority Habitats and Species
designations.source_description: Starting in 2005, the old UK BAP priorities were reviewed and a new list called the UK List of Priority Species and Habitats was published in 2007 after adoption by the Governments of all four UK administrations. The species and habitats on this list help guide conservation actions being taken by the four countries in the UK as part of the UK contribution to the Convention on Biological Diversity.
designations.reporting_category: Biodiversity Action Plan UK list of priority species
designations.designation_description: The UK List of Priority Species and Habitats contains 1150 species and 65 habitats that have been listed as priorities for conservation action under the UK Biodiversity Action Plan (UK BAP).
